title-group.article-title: LESSONS LEARNT BY THE SURVIVORS OF JAMAICA's FINANCIAL SECTOR CRISIS

abstract.p: A growing acceptance of the regularity of financial market failures has led to numerous policy suggestions for increasing and maintaining the stability of the financial system. These suggestions are usually based on attempts to unearth the reasons for the failure of financial institutions. In this study, instead of conducting a postmortem on the failed institutions, the Jamaican case study is used to highlight the critical lessons learnt by managers and regulators of financial institutions that survived a severe financial sector crisis. The institutions that were able to successfully withstand the period of instability have learned important lessons on how to minimize their susceptibility to the negative effects of financial instability, and to diminish the likelihood of a recurrence of the crisis. This paper seeks to highlight these lessons, as well as the lessons enunciated by the regulators and policy-makers. Many of these lessons are, however, not new and should have been obvious to all interested parties. It is therefore argued that if future financial sector crises are to be avoided in Jamaica and other developing countries, the hard-learned lessons of the past must not be ignored or forgotten.
